data.text: Contents
Appointment of Secondment on a permanent basis ..................................................... 9
Introduction

A secondment is where an employee temporarily takes on a role within another Directorate/Department, moves into another post within the same Directorate/Department or within an external organisation for a specific period of time and can be effective in:
Providing cover during the absence of the substantive post holder;
Providing an opportunity for career development, to gain further experience and/or to undertake project work;
Ensure continuity of service during a period of organisational change;
Retention of staff;
Transfer of expertise;
Assigning a project or specific piece of work.

Secondments usually last for between 6 and 12 months but no less than 3 months. They may, in exceptional circumstances, be extended beyond this period, for example if there is a longer project and requires a secondment for the duration. But may be more appropriately filled through a substantive or fixed-term appointment. Regular reviews should take place during the period of secondment generally half way through the duration. Training and support should be provided to ensure the secondee has the opportunity to develop fully in the temporary role.
Scope

By providing a framework for the management of secondments, the aim of this policy is to ensure that the benefits of secondments for both the employee and the organisation are optimised, that secondments are offered fairly, and that they are managed consistently

The policy covers the management of secondments within and outside the Trust. It does not specifically address the management of staff on secondment to the Trust from another employer, although the same good practice principles should apply
This policy does not apply to medical staff, seconded students and employees solely employed on the bank
All secondments are to be planned and supported throughout the process and managed effectively
Secondment opportunities should be available to all staff and will be advertised via the Trust Intranet. The advertisement must clearly state that the post is:
a) A secondment opportunity
b) Give details of the anticipated duration of the secondment.
The Secondment policy must be referenced as part of the recruitment literature.
Where an individual requests a secondment opportunity as part of a personal development plan, this will be arranged separately from the usual recruitment procedures.

All secondment opportunities will be subject to open competition and interviews will therefore be carried out in line with the Operational Recruitment & Selection Procedures. N.B. Exceptions may be made in certain circumstances, for example where an applicant's post is at risk of redundancy.

Where an employee applying for a secondment is subject to a live disciplinary, performance or capability (ill health) warning, or where the requirements of their last appraisal have not been met, this may mean that the secondment request is turned down.
Definitions

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Director of Workforce Services and Strategic Planning
The Director of Workforce Services and Strategic Planning has overall responsibility for the policy and has delegated responsibility to the Associate Director of Resourcing.
Associate Director of Resourcing

The Associate Director of Resourcing is responsible for the implementation of the Policy across the organisation and will ensure that the policy is updated in line with all current and new legislation.
Workforce Services

Workforce Services will ensure compliance with NHS Employment Check Standards, as appropriate for internal secondments, and that all relevant information is recorded on ESR and employee files, and advise managers on the application of the policy.
Managers
The secondee's manager must liaise with HR before recruiting to all secondments and  follow  the  Trust  Recruitment  and  Selection  Policy  when  appointing  to  the secondment.

The secondee's manager must ensure that the secondee has the necessary local and corporate induction. The appropriate development programme and review periods must be agreed with the secondee and new manager. Managers should refer to the Trusts Appraisal Policy as necessary. The secondee may require some development and training to facilitate their transition into the secondment and this should be discussed within the first 2 weeks of the secondment.
The secondee's manager must address any issues in relation to attendance and conduct issues should they arise in line with the Trust Policies.

It is at the discretion of the substantive manager to release the employee for a secondment opportunity. Managers should make careful consideration of the benefits that secondments can offer and subsequent back filling of the position

Substantive managers should remain in contact with the secondee throughout the secondment. If organisational change is proposed, substantive managers should communicate the potential effects of this on the secondee's substantive post and ensure they are involved in the consultation process as per the Organisational Change policy

All parties (secondee, the secondee manager and substantive manager) must sign and agree to the secondment arrangements on Appendix 1 and attach a copy of this to the appropriate payroll form once necessary clearances have been received.

Terms and conditions of secondments will be agreed with the secondee manager at the appointment stage and guidance must be sought through the Trust's Recruitment Policy. If a member of staff wishes to undertake a secondment with another employer (including another Trust), unless it will almost always be necessary for the Trust, employer and the potential secondee first to agree terms for the secondment. This will include liability for the secondee's pay and conditions, their acts and omissions, their personal safety, their access to and use of confidential information and the application of relevant procedures including any relating to performance, conduct and sickness.

As part of agreeing the secondment, managers should define roles and responsibilities and set out their expectations of the member of staff in terms of reporting arrangements for sickness absence, requesting annual leave, appraisal and other relevant day-to-day management issues.
Managers should define the role and responsibilities of the secondment to the member of staff and identify capabilities, expectations and responsibilities within performance management

On completing the secondment, the secondee may also require reorientation and updating to help them acclimatise back to their substantive role. The member of staff is required to participate in and complete this training and development as a condition of their secondment.

Should the secondment need to be extended the secondee manager and substantive manager must agree the new end date of the secondment. The secondee manager must meet with the secondee to discuss the proposed new end date. Once agreed, a letter should be sent to the secondee following this meeting within 5 working days.
Employee
An individual member of staff who wishes to express interest in a secondment opportunity, must advise his/her manager of the same and seek their consent prior to making an application.
Staff that are eligible for secondment opportunities must apply under the Trust's Recruitment Policy and obtain agreement from their substantive manager to release them from their substantive post.
Staff should consider the secondment opportunity and how this will develop their personal and career development in line with the Trusts Appraisal Policy.
All secondees must familiarise themselves with the relevant organisational procedures and working practices.
Secondees are responsible for raising any issues relating to the secondment directly with their secondee manager.
Secondees should remain in contact with their substantive manager throughout their Secondment.
Should the secondment period be extended the secondee must request an extension from their substantive manager.

Employees are not automatically entitled to be released on secondment and should refer to the Trust's Grievance policy if they feel they have been treated unfairly. A member of staff who feels that their request has been unreasonably refused, can raise a grievance under the Grievance and Disputes Procedure.
Employee Relations
Employee Relations are responsible for providing advice to managers and staff in the event of concerns raised about secondments and the relevant process.
Procedure
Permanent members of staff and fixed term appointments in substantive posts may apply for secondment opportunities where appropriate.

Any offer of secondment is subject to agreement by the secondee Manager and the substantive Manager responsible for the employee's substantive post. Any such agreement must also be discussed and documented at offer stage.

The secondee has the right to return to their substantive post at the end of the agreed secondment period on the same pay band and salary point. (These may be reviewed to reflect any national pay awards). Should the secondee's substantive role change or potentially cease to exist as a result of organisational change or reorganisation, the employee will be consulted in line with the Trust's Organisational change policy.

The substantive Manager has the right to reasonably refuse the employee leave to undertake the secondment if their absence is likely to prove too disruptive to the service. Where this occurs employees will be entitled to receive written reasons for refusal, Appendix

The secondee must give their substantive Manager at least 1-month's notice of the commencement of any period of secondment. This allows time for the substantive post Manager to make arrangements for the cover of the secondee's work during their absence. This period may be waived with the mutual agreement of all parties concerned.

The secondee's terms and conditions including salary, during the term of the secondment, will be adjusted to reflect those associated with the terms of the advertised position (at the end of the secondment the secondee will return to their substantive terms and conditions). If the secondment is advertised as the same grade, the secondee will retain their existing terms and conditions.
End of the secondment
The terms and duration of the secondment will be set out in writing to the employee.
The end of the agreed secondment, if not extended, must be planned well in advance by all parties (at least 4 weeks before the end of the secondment).
A secondment may be terminated early by the agreement of all parties. If a secondment is to be terminated prematurely by either party a minimum of four weeks' notice in writing must be given.

In exceptional circumstances, the Trust retains the right to curtail a secondment immediately. For example in the event of unforeseen clinical, organisational or business circumstances which would in the opinion of the appropriate HR lead
render the continuation of the secondment impracticable, e.g. pandemic, implementation of sustained business continuity protocols.
Appointment of secondment on a permanent basis

Where approval is given to appoint into the seconded post on a permanent basis, it does not provide an automatic right for the employee seconded to become permanently employed into the post. The post must be advertised and the appointment made, in open competition, in accordance with the Trust's Recruitment
& Selection Policy. Any appointment made must comply with the Trust's Equal Opportunities Policy.
If the seconded post is to be advertised as fixed term or permanent and the secondee is the successful applicant there will be no right to return to the original role at a future point
External secondments

Where approval is given for employees to take up secondments with external Organisations (the ‘host'), it will be the Manager's responsibility to ensure that the host Organisation makes provision to cross charge for salary and pension contributions. During this period the member of staff will continue to be employed on their usual terms and conditions of employment with the exception of salary, which may vary as appropriate (i.e. the terms that they are employed on by their employer, the seconding organisation).
If relevant a staff change form should be completed and forwarded to Workforce to ensure correct pay and notification of location.

Whilst day to day control will be with the host organisation, management of the employee will remain with the Trust. For example discipline, grievance and sickness absence to be reported in accordance with the Trust sickness policy (not the host organisations sickness policy), but the staff member must also notify the host organisation of their sickness.
Where Memorandum of Understandings (MoU) are in place, other arrangements for temporary secondments may apply as set out in the MoU, e.g. with ICS or NHSE/I.
Professional registration

Staff whose substantive role requires them to maintain a professional registration are responsible for ensuring that their registration is maintained during the period of their secondment. If the secondee's professional registration lapses they will risk
termination of their substantive role.

Where possible, efforts will be made to configure the secondment to support the maintenance of professional registration within the role. Alternatively, the member of staff may need to undertake occasional bank shifts to fulfil their professional registration requirements. This should be negotiated as part of each secondment agreement.
Organisational change

Substantive Managers should take particular care to ensure that staff on secondment are not disadvantaged in the consultation surrounding, or the implementation of, any organisational change affecting their substantive role.

Although managers are not expected to delay the implementation of an organisational change, e.g. restructure, because a member of staff is on secondment, it might be possible to redeploy the secondee in accordance with the relevant Organisational Change Policy but, if practicable, delay their start date until the end of the secondment.
Training requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Recruitment Team.
Monitoring and audit
The Permanent Recruitment team will monitor and analyse data and will use the data to monitor the fair implementation of the policy.
